content.raw: I'm also curious how this works with `use_dynamic_moi_rescaling` set to false. I wonder if it is still sensitive to `sor`
content.html: I'm also curious how this works with use_dynamic_moi_rescaling set to false. I wonder if it is still sensitive to sor

content.raw: It doesn't seem to make a difference; the `sor` parameter is more significant. I would change this value to false (to match its [default value](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/f2b9358f5fd94c5d2bcc1875d4180bcc964f4be1/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-180)) or just delete the element, since it's kind of a hack.
content.html: It doesn't seem to make a difference; the sor parameter is more significant. I would change this value to false (to match its default value) or just delete the element, since it's kind of a hack.

content.raw:
Hi @sloretz , thanks for the tutorial! 

What do you mean by "the torque is always measured as a force applied at a distance from the joint." ? 
In the SDF definition we explicitly write that "the point w.r.t. which the torque is expressed is the joint frame origin", I don't know if you are meaning that, or if the existing SDF definition is clear enough (see https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/130/position-part-of-force_torque-sensor-pose).
content.html:
Hi @sloretz , thanks for the tutorial!

What do you mean by "the torque is always measured as a force applied at a distance from the joint." ? In the SDF definition we explicitly write that "the point w.r.t. which the torque is expressed is the joint frame origin", I don't know if you are meaning that, or if the existing SDF definition is clear enough (see https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/130/position-part-of-force_torque-sensor-pose).

content.raw: Thanks for the feedback. To be honest I misunderstood the documentation in the SDF specification. After reading it again I see that it's actually very clear. I'll remove the sentence I wrote and copy from the SDF spec.
content.html: Thanks for the feedback. To be honest I misunderstood the documentation in the SDF specification. After reading it again I see that it's actually very clear. I'll remove the sentence I wrote and copy from the SDF spec.

content.raw: I think there is a missing "is" .
content.html: I think there is a missing "is" .

content.raw: I don't know if this is the level of detail that you think is reasonable for this kind of tutorials, but it may be worth mentioning that off-the-shelf six-axis F/T sensors are typically rigid connection (i.e. fixed joints) between two rigid bodies (see https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/940/force-torque-sensor-forcetorquesensorcc#comment-9485945). Hence the modeling of a direct `force_torque` sensor measuring the force-torque exchanged through a revolute joint is typically reasonable if one disregards the effect of the ``rigid body'' placed in between the force-torque sensor fixed joint and the revolute joint.
content.html: I don't know if this is the level of detail that you think is reasonable for this kind of tutorials, but it may be worth mentioning that off-the-shelf six-axis F/T sensors are typically rigid connection (i.e. fixed joints) between two rigid bodies (see https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/940/force-torque-sensor-forcetorquesensorcc#comment-9485945). Hence the modeling of a direct force_torque sensor measuring the force-torque exchanged through a revolute joint is typically reasonable if one disregards the effect of the ``rigid body'' placed in between the force-torque sensor fixed joint and the revolute joint.

content.raw:
Detail about modeling sensor on real robots is perfect for a tutorial! Rephrasing your comments to make sure I understand:

Modeling a force/torque sensor as being part of a revolute link makes sense if the distance from the real world sensor to the joint origin is small enough that the error doesn't matter, such as:

![force_torque_on_revolute.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/2579464437-force_torque_on_revolute.png)

Otherwise a rigid body should be divided into two links with a fixed joint at the location of the force/torque sensor

![force_torque_on_fixed.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/29110018-force_torque_on_fixed.png)
content.html:
Detail about modeling sensor on real robots is perfect for a tutorial! Rephrasing your comments to make sure I understand:

Modeling a force/torque sensor as being part of a revolute link makes sense if the distance from the real world sensor to the joint origin is small enough that the error doesn't matter, such as:

Otherwise a rigid body should be divided into two links with a fixed joint at the location of the force/torque sensor

content.html: It could make it more intuitive to also have a cylinder visual connecting the joint origin to the sphere.

content.raw:
As an example, this is what I added on the gif:

~~~
        <visual name="visual_cylinder">
          <pose>0 0 -0.75 0 0 0</pose>
          <geometry>
            <cylinder>
              <radius>0.0100000</radius>
              <length>1.5</length>
            </cylinder>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
~~~

While reviewing this tutorial I noticed that the force / torque sensor visualization wasn't working. So I made a [gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2653/force-torque-sensor-visualization-using/diff) fixing it.

I also made a little gif to demonstrate the visual, using this tutorial. Feel free to use the gif here if you want:

https://github.com/chapulina/gzgif/blob/master/force_torque_sensor.gif
